title: 109_s624
content: The "Patriot Penalty Elimination Act of 2005" allows for income preservation pay for reserves serving on active duty in support of a contingency operation. The "Patriot Penalty Elimination Act of 2005" authorizes income preservation pay for eligible reserve members serving on active duty outside the United States for at least 6 out of 12 consecutive months. The "Patriot Penalty Elimination Act of 2005" allows income preservation pay for eligible reserve members on active duty outside the US for 6 out of 12 consecutive months. The amount payable is based on the difference between preservice earned income and military service income. The total income preservation pay for a member on active duty cannot exceed $50,000. The preservice average monthly earned income is calculated by dividing the total earned income for the 12 months before the first service month by 12. The military service average monthly income is determined by a specific calculation. The income preservation pay for a member on active duty is calculated based on their earned income and basic pay. The total amount payable is due in one lump sum within 30 days of release from active duty. The Secretary concerned may make advance payments under certain conditions. The Secretary may make advance payments to a member on active duty under certain conditions, with the option to waive recoupment if it is deemed against equity or the best interests of the United States. Definitions for "earned income" and "service month" are provided in this section. The section discusses the termination of authority after five years and recharacterization of payment for reserves on active duty. It also includes a clerical amendment to the table of sections. SEC. 3. READY RESERVE-NATIONAL GUARD EMPLOYEE CREDIT. Subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new section 45J for the Ready Reserve-National Guard Employee Credit, effective January 1, 2003, for active-duty service. The Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit under section 38 is 50% of the actual compensation amount or $30,000 for each employee. The actual compensation amount is the pay for days of qualified active duty. No credit is allowed for days when the employee was not scheduled to work. Qualified active duty is defined as active duty outside the United States for a period exceeding 179 days or for an indefinite period, entitling an employee to reemployment rights and benefits. The curr_chunk discusses definitions related to benefits, compensation, and Ready Reserve-National Guard employees. It also mentions that certain rules apply and the section does not apply to termination. The section discusses the termination clause and amendments to the general business credit and denial of double benefit in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by inserting a new section after section 45I in subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. Section 45J establishes Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit, effective for expenses incurred after December 31, 2004.
